n2 = 0.5y
n = n1 + 0.5n2 = x + 0.25y Substituting n, n1 and n2 into Equation 6.23: CxHy + (x + 0.25y)O2 = xCO2 + 0.5yH2O     [6.24] Therefore, 1 mole of fuel will produce x moles of CO2. For example, if a gas turbine produces 20 MW of power at a thermal efficiency of 35%, the thermal input required is (20/0.35) = 57.14 MW. If methane is burnt, whose LHV is about 50 MJ/kg, a fuel flow rate of (57.14/50) 1.143 kg/s will be required and the CO2 emissions will be 3.14 kg/s. If kerosene with a LHV of about 43 MJ/kg is used, the fuel flow required is (57.14/43) = 1.329 kg/s and the CO2 emissions will be 4.17 kg/s. This represents about a 16% increase in fuel flow and a 32% increase in CO2. (It is assumed that there is no change in gas turbine performance due to the change in fuel from methane to kerosene.
